Constantine – The City of Hanging Bridges

It is the third-largest city in Algeria and the capital of the country’s eastern region. Known as the City of Hanging Bridges due to its unique geographical landscape, it is built on a solid limestone rock, giving it a distinctive appearance and earning it the title "The City of Ancient Rock."

 With a history spanning over 2,300 years, it was originally known as Cirta and served as the capital of the Kingdom of Numidia before falling under Roman rule.
 It received its current name in 313 AD in honor of Emperor Constantine the Great.
 Throughout the centuries, it remained an important cultural and historical center, preserving its rich heritage to this day.

The Emir Abdelkader Mosque is a modern architectural masterpiece, designed in the Andalusian-Maghreb style and inaugurated in 1994. It can accommodate over 15,000 worshippers and features two towering minarets standing at 107 meters. The mosque is adorned with intricate Quranic inscriptions and houses an Islamic university specializing in Sharia and jurisprudence.

The Palace of Ahmed Bey is one of the most magnificent Ottoman-era palaces in Algeria, built between 1826 and 1835 as the residence of Ahmed Bey, the last ruler of Constantine under Ottoman rule. It boasts over 120 rooms decorated with Andalusian-style mosaics, expansive gardens with rare plants, and beautifully painted ceilings depicting scenes from that era.
 
 The palace is open Sunday to Thursday, from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM.
 
Entrance fee is approximately 200 Algerian Dinars (about 1.5 USD).

The Medersa of Constantine, also known as the Pashas School, dates back to the 18th century and served as a major educational hub for Islamic studies and Arabic language. It features traditional Islamic architecture, including elegant archways, open courtyards, and Quranic inscriptions on its walls. During French colonization, the school was closed for a period but was later restored as a cultural symbol of Algerian heritage.

The Tomb of Massinissa dates back to the 3rd century BC and is believed to be the final resting place of King Massinissa, the founder of the Numidian kingdom and a key military leader in North Africa. Perched on a high hill, the tomb simple yet symbolic design reflects the grandeur of the Numidian civilization. The surrounding area was once an important trade and cultural center.

The Ain Fouara Roman Baths are among the oldest hydrothermal facilities in Algeria, used since the Roman era for healing and relaxation. These baths attracted aristocrats and travelers seeking therapeutic mineral-rich waters. Today, remnants of the ancient walls and basins remain, showcasing the Romans advanced engineering techniques in water heating and thermal architecture.
Located in the center of Constantine, it is a major religious and cultural landmark in Algeria.
Located in the heart of Constantine, near Martyrs Square, it is one of the most important Ottoman palaces in Algeria.
Located in the old city center, it was an important educational center during the Ottoman period.

Cirta Museum

The Cirta Museum is one of the oldest and most important museums in Algeria, showcasing a vast collection of artifacts from the Numidian, Roman, and Byzantine eras. The museum houses statues, mosaics, coins, and rare manuscripts, making it an essential destination for history enthusiasts.

 Open from Sunday to Thursday, from 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM.

Entrance fee: 150 DZD (~1 USD).
Located in the Kasbah district, near the hanging bridges in the center of Constantine.

Ghabat El Wahch, meaning "Forest of the Beast," is a vast green space located on the outskirts of Constantine. The name originates from old legends and local stories that suggest wild animals, especially wolves, once roamed this forest in the past. Today, it serves as a popular recreational area for locals and visitors, offering fresh air, hiking trails, and scenic picnic spots. The forest is home to diverse plant species and wildlife, making it an excellent escape into nature.

Tiddis is an ancient Numidian and Roman archaeological site perched on a hilltop near Constantine. It offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding valleys. The ruins include Roman roads, a forum, houses, and water systems, showcasing the blend of Numidian and Roman architectural styles. Tiddis is an ideal spot for history enthusiasts and nature lovers alike.

Oued Rhumel is the iconic river that carved Constantine’s famous gorges, creating the city dramatic landscape. The river winds through deep canyons beneath Constantines bridges, offering spectacular views. It has played a crucial role in the city history and provides stunning natural scenery for sightseeing and photography.
Located on the outskirts of Constantine, it is one of the city largest green spaces, ideal for outdoor activities.
Located approximately 30 km from Constantine, Tiddis is a hilltop archaeological site with breathtaking views of the surrounding valleys.
Flowing through the heart of Constantine, Oued Rhumel is a key geographical feature that shaped the city landscape.
